title: Sergio Escudero (footballer, born 1988)
text:
Sergio Escudero (エスクデロ 競飛王, "Esukudero Seruhio"; ; born September 1, 1988) is a professional <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> player for <a href="Thai%20League%201">Thai League 1</a> club <a href="Chiangmai%20United%20F.C.">Chiangmai United</a>. Born in Spain, he has represented Japan internationally. He is the son of Argentine-Japanese footballer <a href="Sergio%20Escudero%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201964%29">Sergio Ariel Escudero</a>.
Biography.
As the son of a former Argentine-Japanese footballer of <a href="Sergio%20Escudero%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201964%29">the same name</a>, he was born to <a href="Spanish%20settlement%20in%20Argentina">Argentine parents of Spanish descent</a> in Spain, and thus held dual Argentine and Spanish citizenship. In 2007, he acquired Japanese citizenship automatically as a result of his father's naturalization. Escudero is a cousin of <a href="Dami%C3%A1n%20Escudero">Damián Escudero</a> and nephew of <a href="Osvaldo%20Escudero">Osvaldo Escudero</a>.
Career.
When Escudero was three years old, he moved to <a href="Japan">Japan</a> because of his father's work and joined the local club team. After living in Japan for five years, he moved to <a href="Argentina">Argentina</a> and Escudero began his career with the <a href="Club%20Atl%C3%A9tico%20V%C3%A9lez%20S%C3%A1rsfield">Vélez Sársfield</a> youth team, where his father, also named <a href="Sergio%20Escudero%20%28footballer%20born%201964%29">Sergio Ariel Escudero</a> and uncle <a href="Osvaldo%20Salvador%20Escudero">Osvaldo Salvador Escudero</a> have played. Then he was called up to the U-15 <a href="Argentina%20national%20football%20team">Argentina national team</a> training camp.
In 2001, Escudero returned to Japan and joined <a href="Kashiwa%20Reysol">Kashiwa Reysol</a> junior youth team in Chiba and later moved to <a href="Urawa%20Red%20Diamonds">Urawa Red Diamonds</a> junior youth team in Saitama. He scored many goals in youth level league matches and contracted with Urawa Reds in 2005. Playing as a <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">forward</a>, Escudero made his debut as a professional on April 15, 2005, against <a href="Albirex%20Niigata">Albirex Niigata</a> at the age of 16 years, 8 months and 21 days and he became the second youngest <a href="J.%20League">J. League</a> Division 1 player after <a href="Takayuki%20Morimoto">Takayuki Morimoto</a>. In 2006, German outfit <a href="VfB%20Stuttgart">VfB Stuttgart</a> were interested in him but Urawa refused to release him.
On June 11, 2007, he obtained his Japanese citizenship and therefore he had a chance to play for the <a href="Japan%20national%20under-20%20football%20team">Japan U-20 team</a> at <a href="2007%20FIFA%20U-20%20World%20Cup">2007 FIFA U-20 World Cup</a> in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. However he failed to make it to the tournament since the squad was submitted before he became a Japanese citizen. In May 2008, he joined the <a href="Japan%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">U-23 national team</a> which played at the <a href="2008%20Toulon%20Tournament">2008 Toulon Tournament</a> and scored a goal against <a href="Ivory%20Coast%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">Ivory Coast</a>.
On July 17, 2012, Escudero joined South Korean outfit <a href="FC%20Seoul">FC Seoul</a> on a six-month loan deal. He received number 26 and scored his debut goal on July 21. He scored 4 goals and provided 3 assists in the end of the season. His loan was made permanent in December. He scored the opening goal and assisted <a href="Dejan%20Damjanovic">Dejan Damjanovic</a>'s 2:2 Equalizer in the <a href="2013%20AFC%20Champions%20League%20Final">2013 AFC Champions League Final</a> match against China powerhouse <a href="Guangzhou%20Evergrande">Guangzhou Evergrande</a> in October 26, 2013. His impressive performance made him <a href="Man%20of%20the%20Match">Man of the Match</a>.
On 25 February 2015, Escudero signed a two-year contract with <a href="Chinese%20Super%20League">Chinese Super League</a> side <a href="Jiangsu%20Guoxin-Sainty">Jiangsu Guoxin-Sainty</a>.
